intro: Gahnia howeana, commonly known as the Howe's grass tree, is a distinctive member of the Cyperaceae family. It is native to the coastal regions of southeastern Australia, particularly in New South Wales. The plant is characterized by its tall, narrow leaves and a single, upright flowering spike that produces small, greenish flowers. It thrives in sandy or rocky soils and is adapted to coastal conditions, including salt spray and strong winds. Gahnia howeana plays an important ecological role in its habitat, providing shelter and food for various native wildlife species.
